title: 1424Wait Harvard has the cure for breast cancer but they won't spend any of their 50 billion dollar

Wow these people are even more evil than I ever imagined. posted 2 days ago by PiratePatriotParrot 217 comments award share report block Matt Walsh @MattWalshBlog • 2d Wait Harvard has the cure for breast cancer but they won't spend any of their 50 billion dollar endowment to develop it and instead demand that the taxpayers give them the money? Wow these people are even more evil than I ever imagined. 60 Minutes @60Minutes • 3d Harvard researcher Joan Brugge says her work has the potential to prevent breast cancer, but she was notified last spring that her federal funding was terminated. “It was just like a gut punch. My knees buckled, and I had to sit down,” she says.

Deplora 46 points 2 days ago She says her work has potential to prevent (not cure) breast cancer.  I can't be bothered to watch this, but "breast cancer" is a whole bunch of different types of cancer, with different developmental pathways and different sensitivity/resistance to various treatments.  Nobody has " the cure for breast cancer" or even " the prevention for breast cancer", and nobody ever will.  Most preventive measures that are already proven to be highly effective involve lifestyle changes and self-discipline that most women are unwilling to adhere to (no alcohol use, no getting significantly overweight). There are many thousands of biomedical researchers who are hoping that their idea will prove to be very significant for treating or preventing some common life-shortening or disabling disease.  They can't all be given all the money they want to try to prove their idea actually works. Moose_Antlers 1 points 2 days ago She's wildly overstating what she has. This is the paper she published referring to this breakthrough: https://www.nature.com/articles/s41588-024-01988-0 She's saying that she found a fairly easily detectable pattern in BRCA1+ and BRCA2+ individuals that appears before some of the traditional mutations manifest. This is what's called a biomarker. You can build a test for these things and use the test to screen at-risk patients. The catch is that she's developed no actual test, nor has she done the clinical work to validate her method of screening in real patients. This is really important because we need to know if the test results mean anything. Do they predict that a person is going to develop the disease? If so, how often? If a person tests positive and half the time, nothing happens, it's a terrible test. That has to be studied. She's a long way out from that. She's doing hypothesis generating research and trying to act like she's on the verge of launching a meaningful screening test. Even then, that's not preventing breast cancer. That's early detection of something that's already there in patients where we already know are high risk.
